bullets.text: A linear equation with n variables in standard form: a₁x₁ + a₂x₂ + ... + aₙxₙ = b. Coefficients are aᵢ, b is the constant. Homogeneous if b=0.

A system of linear equations (linear system) is a finite number of linear equations. Standard form for m equations and n variables: a₁₁x₁ + ... + a₁nxn = b₁, ..., am₁x₁ + ... + amnxn = bm. Homogeneous if all bᵢ=0.
A linear system can have no solution (inconsistent), a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions (consistent).
For 2 variables (lines): no solution (parallel distinct), unique solution (intersect at one point), infinitely many solutions (coincide).

For 3 variables (planes): no solution (parallel distinct or lines of intersection don't intersect), unique solution (intersect at a point), infinitely many solutions with 1 parameter (intersect along a line), infinitely many solutions with 2 parameters (coincide).
An augmented matrix represents a linear system. Coefficients on LHS, constants on RHS.
Elementary Row Operations: 1. Rᵢ ↔ Rⱼ (Exchanging rows). 2. Rᵢ + cRⱼ (Adding a multiple of a row to another). 3. aRⱼ (Multiplying a row by a nonzero constant).
Performing elementary row operations on the augmented matrix of a linear system preserves its solutions.
Two matrices are row equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by elementary row operations. Row equivalent systems have the same solutions.
Reverse of Rᵢ ↔ Rⱼ is Rᵢ ↔ Rⱼ. Reverse of Rᵢ + cRⱼ is Rᵢ - cRⱼ. Reverse of aRⱼ is (1/a)Rⱼ (a≠0).
Multiplying a row by 0 can change the solution set of a linear system.
Row-Echelon Form (REF): 1. Zero rows are at the bottom. 2. Leading entries move to the right as you go down rows.
A column containing a leading entry is a pivot column; otherwise, it's a non-pivot column.
Reduced Row-Echelon Form (RREF): In REF, plus: 3. Leading entries are 1. 4. Entries above and below leading entries in pivot columns are 0.
RREF is a special case of REF.
An augmented matrix in REF or RREF makes it easy to extract solutions.
Gaussian Elimination: Reduce augmented matrix to REF using elementary row operations.
Gauss-Jordan Elimination: Reduce augmented matrix to RREF using elementary row operations.

Steps for Gaussian Elimination: 1. Find leftmost non-zero column. 2. Swap rows to bring non-zero entry to top. 3. Make entries below the leading entry zero by adding multiples of the top row. 4. Repeat for submatrix below the first row.
Steps for Gauss-Jordan Elimination (continues from Gaussian): 5. Make all leading entries 1. 6. Make entries above leading entries zero by adding multiples of rows.
If augmented matrix is in REF, use back-substitution to find solutions.
If augmented matrix is in RREF, read off solutions directly.
System is inconsistent if and only if the RHS (last column) of the augmented matrix in REF/RREF is a pivot column.
Assign parameters to variables corresponding to non-pivot columns in the LHS of the augmented matrix.
The number of parameters needed equals the number of non-pivot columns.
General solution captures all possible solutions. Parameters (e.g., s, t) can be any real number.

1. Write linear system in standard form. 2. Form augmented matrix. 3. Reduce to REF or RREF (Gaussian/Gauss-Jordan). 4. Check for inconsistency (RHS is pivot column). 5. If consistent, assign parameters to non-pivot columns. 6. If RREF, read solutions. If REF, use back-substitution. 7. Write down general solution.
Number of pivot columns = number of nonzero rows in REF.
A matrix in RREF is also in REF.
